awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: A Low-Cost Cortisol Sensor for Real-Time Stress Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this PFI project is to develop a low-cost cortisol sensing technology for early detection of stress-related diseases. Cortisol is a biomarker used for stress evaluation in human subjects. Increased cortisol levels have been linked to stress-related diseases, including chronic fatigue syndrome, post-traumatic stress disorder, and neurodegenerative diseases including Alzheimer's disease, and multiple sclerosis. Therefore accurate measurement of cortisol in saliva, and sweat, is gaining increasing clinical significance to predict multiple physical and mental diseases. While existing laboratory techniques, such as ELISA and FIA, can provide precise cortisol measurements, they are generally too slow, where a rapid response or intervention is needed. The proposed technology overcomes significant limitations such as the necessity of having specified sample volume to perform a test, total testing time, and expensive optical detection unit. The substantial advantage of the proposed technology is to produce cortisol results within few minutes and can replace tedious laboratory-based techniques. This technology will create personalized behavioral intervention to regulate cortisol levels and prevent stress-related health problems for at-risk clinical populations. The proposed cortisol sensing technology will provide solutions to hospitals, diagnostic laboratories, and pharmaceutical industries, which increasingly rely on fast, sensitive, reproducible and fully automated technologies.


The proposed project aims to translate a sensor technology, developed under a previously funded NSF grant, into a low-cost, handheld sensing device to monitor the salivary cortisol levels in point-of-care (POC) monitoring. The FIU team has engineered recognition site of cortisol sensor using antibody- mimic, robust and easily industrially scalable electroactive imprinted polymers that allow to miniaturize device in easily deployable and portable format. In order to translate the sensor into the market, the project will be consolidated into two goals: (i) sensor stability and measurement repeatability, and (ii) reducing cost and size. To accomplish these goals FIU team will 1) develop of high-affinity and reagent-less MIP sensor for Cortisol using novel electroactive monomers and 2) Constructing a low-cost handheld/portable prototype for field use. The proposed cortisol sensor will be capable of sending real-time data from the sensor to the virtual server via a smartphone app. The real-time data will be populated and processed on the virtual machines and will be archived by the user on their personal computer or smartphone app. The project will fortify a cross-university collaboration between the areas of health science and engineering; resulting in interdisciplinary biomedical research training for students, postdoctoral researchers, and faculty.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This PFI Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project focused on developing miniaturized cortisol sensor technology to monitor cortisol levels non-invasively to diagnose stress-related disorders. Cortisol is a crucial biomarker used to evaluate stress in human subjects. Increased cortisol levels have been linked to many stress-related diseases, such as chronic fatigue syndrome, irritable bowel syndrome, and post-traumatic stress disorder. Therefore, accurate cortisol measurement in saliva, serum, plasma, urine, sweat, and hair is gaining increasing clinical significance in predicting multiple physical and mental diseases. Through this PFI-TT project, investigations are carried out to understand the cortisol detection mechanism using molecularly imprinted polymers (MIP) approach. Extensive studies were carried out to optimize the parameters affecting the sensor performance. A novel extended gate Field Effect Transistor (EGFET) based system was designed and developed to get direct measurements of cortisol levels from the MIP sensor. The EGFET sensor was miniaturized into a wearable and handheld device. A low-energy Bluetooth module was developed to inject the MIP sensor data from wearable devices into the smartphone. The miniaturized wearable cortisol sensing device was validated using standard saliva samples for the sensor reproducibility, sensitivity, and cross-reactivity. Through this PFI-TT project, research team explored the commercialization aspects by engaging in the new customer segment discovery. A company was founded to commercialize the research. The project produced one granted patent, five research articles, and two PhD dissertations.   

 

The broader impact /commercial potential of this PFI-TT project is to enable the transition of patented cortisol biosensor technology from diagnosis to continuous health care monitoring. The cortisol sensing technology can improve human well-being by providing an economical means for point-of-care diagnosis. This project demonstrated the potential of the cortisol sensing technology to reach other market segments, such as the healthcare monitoring of athletes, farm workers, and firefighters who often undergo stressful conditions. These groups may benefit from alternative treatments based on the near real-time measurement of cortisol concentrations in saliva. Not limited to cortisol, the project exhibited the use of this technology to detect other vital biomarkers such as testosterone and estrogen. The project contributed to the field of nanotechnology by enabling the creation of nano-biosensors capable of detecting biomarkers in other life-threatening diseases, e.g., cancer, neurological diseases, cardiovascular diseases, etc. Through this project, two Ph.D. students, two postdocs, nine undergraduate students, and four k-12 teachers (most of them are underrepresented) were trained on various aspects of the project, including sensor development, electronics design, and technology commercialization.

 


Last Modified: 01/22/2024
Modified by: Shekhar Bhansali
